text: uh today I want to talk about the
importance of making mistakes
so whether you're fresh out of school or
an experienced professional we've all
made mistakes at some point
but despite the negative connotations of
the word mistakes can actually be a good
thing
mistakes can provide learning and
experience and mistakes can even
facilitate innovation
but for that to happen we need to create
room for making mistakes and one way of
doing just that is by sharing
so during this talk I will try and lead
by example and share a story of a
mistake I made a few months back
so for the past year and a half I've
been working on a project for a customer
specializing in invoice services and Dev
collection and I'm part of the invoice
team and we're essentially responsible
for the system that administers invoices
so from the very moment the invoice is
first created through all the payment
reminders and so on
until we eventually either collect the
payment or send it to Dev collection
uh when I started working on this team
um creating test data was a major
bottleneck for us and this was mainly
due to two reasons
number one manually creating test data
is an extremely tedious and time
consuming process that's not scalable
and it's also very difficult to get good
enough quality in the test data that
you're creating
therefore the second point
production data is often used for
testing which is obviously not a great
practice
so in order to overcome both the TDS
process of manually creating test data
and to be compliant with gdpr
regulations
an API for generating synthetic test
data was developed
and with this API it allows you to
Simply specify the data that you need
for the specific test that you're
running send a request and the API just
randomly generates the rest of the data
and returns to your complete invoice
ready for for testing
so all in all it's a great solution to
our problems
um so at this project I'm working on
implementing automated tests for our
team
but before I run any of these tests I
like to start off with some freshly
generated synthetic test data
so I started by writing a small script
making one request to the API with the
following payload
now what I try to do with this request
is simply just specify as little data as
possible to see what's the minimum
required payload in order to get a
complete invoice from this API
so as you can see I mainly just
specified the supplier ID which is kind
of the customer of which the invoice is
concerning
and the invoice number in order to be
able to find the invoice in our system
once uh the invoice was generated
so wrote the script ran it
but I got no invoice returned back
and I thought to myself that that's a
bit strange
so kill the terminal try to run it once
more and once again nothing I've
returned
and now it also looks like the API had
crashed
so
I restarted the server made sure
everything was up and running everything
looked okay
and ran the request a third time
and once again same result
no invoice returned and the API crashed
so at this point I thought that I had
discovered a bug and being a tester I
love finding bugs so I was kind of happy
with myself
so I went and contacted the developer
responsible for the API and we sat down
had a look at it together
but neither of us could see neither of
us could see anything wrong with the
request
so he said he'd look look at it and get
back to me once it figured out what was
wrong
and I also tried to do some
investigation of My Own by changing up
some of the contents of the payload and
make the requests a few more times
but every time I got the same result
no invoice was returned and the API
crashed
so I was dumped
so a couple days go by and it's pretty
much business as usual
when all of a sudden I get a message
from a colleague working for the same
customer but on the Azure side of things
he asked me if we were running any
automated tests yet
and I said no uh we haven't implemented
any tests yet
and I said okay I was just asking
because we're receiving a lot of invoice
requests
like a lot
I thought hmm now that's a bit strange
but I immediately immediately got
suspicious that it could be related to
the crashing API
so asked if you could check what's the
invoice number of the invoices that
you're getting
and they said yeah it's um two seven
nine eight one two four
and I compared with the invoice number
in my request and could say that it was
different so I was quite relieved and
concluded that it could it had to be
something else it couldn't be couldn't
be me
then the next day another developer
messaged me
and said that he noticed a few days back
that some of the message handling
processes in our test environment such
as the ones handling messages for
incoming invoices
had uh had crashed a few days back due
to it receiving a lot of invoices
and I got a bad feeling in my stomach
and my suspicion grew even further but I
had checked that it wasn't my request so
it couldn't be it couldn't be because of
that
then the next day yet another developer
yet again messages me
and said and I quote
we are receiving a lot of invoices in
tests and our databases are filled up
but the invoice requests just keep
coming in it seems like someone is
conducting a performance test on
steroids
I said I said that it might be due to
this API crashing but I can't pinpoint
exactly what's going wrong
but I thought to myself okay I need to
figure this out now so
I decided to have a closer look at the
source code
and after a few minutes it clicks
and I see what's going on
and I just think to myself
oh
I messed up here
because it turns out
invoice number does not equal invoice
number
rather invoice number
equals number of invoices
so let's have a look at the request
doesn't
that's a hard that's a pretty high
number
that's close to 800 million
every single time I sent that request
not for a system that handles around say
200 000 invoices in each day at most
receiving almost four thousand times
that amount
no wonder it had some struggles
now
what can we learn from this or can we
draw any any positives from this
well let's try
number one I guess
um it highlighted the importance of an
ambiguous variable naming
number two we can safely conclude that
the system cannot handle 800 million
invoices at once
and number three I hope that I brought
the smile to some of your faces during
this talk thank you
foreign
